text: A lot of the people you see walking outside could really use a good ass whooping or a few years of forced manual labor. Nothing crazy like broken bones or being starved on 1200 calories building rockets 16 hours a day, but just enough to put the fear of God into them permanently.

Just noticed that Scott Locklin recommended a book by Halton Arp in his recent blogpost, Halton Arp is a revisionist astronomer that Dr. Ray Peat has repeatedly talked about in interviews and emails as someone who had a ton of obviously correct ideas and was sidelined in science.
Underrated hotspot for paranormal encounters: "on the edge of rural shopping malls."

I think public prayer itself has a stabilizing social role as a ritual outside of the private devotional life, e.g. confession also used to be public in front of the congregation in the past. But it's probably very context dependent, you have to always have the situation in mind.

Have been brainstorming the concept of "Eurosgiving" for almost a year now

I still do not know what it entails except being a somehow more European version of Thanksgiving with no real history and substance or even reason to exist. Also we probably are going to have to use the Canadian Thanksgiving date due to complicated geopolitical strategic reasons.

I've said it before but if I saw Rory Stewart walking around my hometown I would immediately start packing my bags and leave as soon as possible and just run. Something horrible is about to happen soon. There will be blood on the streets. It's like seeing the Horseman of Death.

I think the degree to which your political instincts are correct is the same as the degree to which you are scared from Rory Stewart. If he looks like a harmless and naive schmuck you're probably easy prey yourself. The more terrifying he seems the closer you are to the truth.

If you live in Cambodia or some place like that and see someone like Rory Stewart walking around it 100% means something monstrous is going to happen. People will die. There will be some communist revolution or a radical Islamic group will take power. Rory Stewart is the Mothman.
Not my Shabbos, not my goyim.

Emailer question: Dr. Peat, I have been having daily seizures lately, I have hearing loss in my left ear, also I was recently diagnosed with cancer and Peyronie's disease.

Dr. Ray Peat response: Have you had your Vitamin D level tested? It's also important to get enough Calcium.

During the Falklands War the British deployed elite Nepalese Gurkha units against Argentinian soldiers and supposedly ordered/allowed them to rape prisoners to racially humiliate the Argentinians as a terror tactic.

The Argentinian military government presented itself as the defenders of Western civilization. I'm pretty sure the Gurkhas are the exact people Alexander the Great erected the gates to keep out of Europe. You can see who actually controls them today too.

For the record I think every British soldier who fought there was also a total patriot who should be celebrated for fighting for his motherland

The way that H.P. Lovecraft describes Shoggoths is very similar to Gene Wolfe's aborigines in The Fifth Head of Cerberus and other stories - perfect mimics who can mirror any form of life they come in contact with. The Shoggoths become the Old Ones just as the Annese aboriginals.

E.g. in At the Mountains of Madness - Chapter 10 there is a paragraph about how when the Old Ones are replaced by the Shoggoths the quality of their art declines abruptly and the aborigines in Wolfe's novel are said not to be able to use tools and thus have very poor handwriting.

Lovecraft actually uses bacteriological language for the Shoggoth and describes them as agglutinations of unicellular organisms while Wolfe in FHoC describes the Shadow Children as spores or bacteria or such instead. But I think the parallels are interesting. Wolfe did read him.
